messages:
[{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-03-02 18:56:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-08 05:31:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

I like where this is going.

I think the only wart I see beyond your testing comment is the way you're calling pip."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-15 12:04:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I need more convincing that this should be a feature of pbr. I think it enables bad code management practices. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128335.html'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2018-03-15 17:23:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Doug,

I have read your mailing list post, and perhaps what you describe there is the correct way to go for OpenStack and neutron/horizon.  I'm not going to argue whether this or your suggestions are the right choices for those projects.

I will say that, in general, I believe that a coordinated multi-repo project is a legitimate thing to support.  Any large project suffers the same issues about how to organize the codebase.  Some fragment into libraries, others go all-in on a monorepo.  Others may chose the coordinated multi-repo approach, where the individual components are developed in tandem and make coordinated releases.

Zuul makes this process very easy for those who wish to use it, and I think it would be great if PBR did as well.  I personally think it can be a really good model, and is a good alternative to solutions such as this: https://www.visualstudio.com/learn/gvfs-design-history/

Again, I think it's important for us to decide the direction we want to take horizon and neutron, but I think that should be separate from the availability of this feature, which I think stands on its own merit."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-26 14:55:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I also can't say I agree with this. While I get the concerns of the neutron and horizon teams, I also agree with Doug that those projects should be using libraries, should they wish to share functionality. Things like nova, horizon, neutron et al are applications - not libraries. The fact that they have 'setup.py' files in the first place is, IMO, a mistake that we're only now getting in a position to clean up (thanks to the PTI move from 'setup.py build_sphinx' to calling 'sphinx-build' directly). I don't want use repeating the mistakes of the past."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-26 14:55:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I also can't say I agree with this. While I get the concerns of the
 > neutron and horizon teams, I also agree with Doug that those
 > projects should be using libraries, should they wish to share
 > functionality. Things like nova, horizon, neutron et al are
 > applications - not libraries. The fact that they have 'setup.py'
 > files in the first place is, IMO, a mistake that we're only now
 > getting in a position to clean up (thanks to the PTI move from
 > 'setup.py build_sphinx' to calling 'sphinx-build' directly). I
 > don't want use repeating the mistakes of the past.

*thanks to things like the PTI move..."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2019-07-29 14:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

[{'created': '2018-03-02 18:56:35.000000000', 'message': "WIP Add siblings command

This is the logic extracted from the zuul-jobs tox job install-siblings
feature. While it's great and works mostly well - there are two issues.

The first is that it's not super convenient to unit-test library files in
ansible roles. That makes working on logic a bit more delicate than one
might prefer.

The second is that it's hard for a developer to re-create the same state
locally.

As the tox-siblings logic fundamentally requires the main project to use
pbr anyway, we can be assured that in all cases where one wants to use
it that pbr will be present.

This is not a straight copy of the code from zuul-jobs. It has been
reworked to be a class and to use pkg_resources instead of using pip as
a library to read a requirements file generated by pip freeze.

The code works now, but the bash script used to test it is not the right
way to go about this. Instead, we need some real unit tests.

Change-Id: I77bc42674596d9296a503c20dd1e9156bf019460
"}]
commit_message:
WIP Add siblings command

This is the logic extracted from the zuul-jobs tox job install-siblings
feature. While it's great and works mostly well - there are two issues.

The first is that it's not super convenient to unit-test library files in
ansible roles. That makes working on logic a bit more delicate than one
might prefer.

The second is that it's hard for a developer to re-create the same state
locally.

As the tox-siblings logic fundamentally requires the main project to use
pbr anyway, we can be assured that in all cases where one wants to use
it that pbr will be present.

This is not a straight copy of the code from zuul-jobs. It has been
reworked to be a class and to use pkg_resources instead of using pip as
a library to read a requirements file generated by pip freeze.

The code works now, but the bash script used to test it is not the right
way to go about this. Instead, we need some real unit tests.

Change-Id: I77bc42674596d9296a503c20dd1e9156bf019460

commit_message:
Set defaults for zuul_work_dir and bindep_dir

All things being equal, zuul_work_dir should always default to
zuul.project.src_dir and bindep_dir should always default to
zuul_work_dir so that jobs can override both by setting zuul_work_dir.

At the moment setting up default values in jobs and playbooks involves a
lot of copy-pasta that we don't always get right. Setting them here
should take care of it comprehensively while stll allowing job-level
override.

Change-Id: I8c26856742962430563a2d6524c82610cf5d4a29

commit_message:
Add zuul_work_dir defaults to base-test

We can use this change to test whether this works or not with some
depends-on patches. If it does, this should allow us to set sane
defaults for these two.

Change-Id: Ied2bf188d5c15bf2b7bd7350d9a7274421c9dabf

commit_message:
IPA does not boot up after cleaning reboot for 'redfish' bios interface

The clean steps of 'redfish' bios interface does not set up deploy ramdisk
before initiating the cleaning reboot of bare metal.

Change-Id: I979358ead1e19f9b24f23117d0cba3479e33707b
Story: 2006217
Task: 35810

messages:
[{'account_id': 30209, 'date': '2019-07-26 07:02:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-07-26 08:30:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-26 12:12:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-26 13:04:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

(1 comment)

Someone other than me will need to approve this patch anyway, so I'll just remove my vote and see how they feel."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-26 14:10:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Given the precedent with the previous tags in the same family I think the lack of _ is good and fine.

I tend to think that there shouldn't be any underscores in any of the tags with a particular module. Doing so causes the hierarchy provided by the python packages to be inconsistent. If you think you need an underscore in your tag, that may need another leg in the hierarchy is desired.

Remember that tags can be accessed like this too:

    os_traits.hw.cpu.x86.AVX512VNNI"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-26 15:12:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Huaqiang, let us know if you need this in a release with any urgency.'}, {'account_id': 30209, 'date': '2019-07-29 02:11:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Eric, yes I need a release to enable this feature further in Nova, please help for a release. Thanks'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-29 13:53:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

[{'created': '2019-07-26 07:02:40.000000000', 'message': 'CPU: add a trait for AVX512-VNNI support

Add a new standard trait HW_CPU_X86_AVX512VNNI for the support
of CPU AVX512-VNNI instructions.

AVX512-VNNI is the vector network instruction set which is described in
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AVX-512#New_instructions_in_AVX-512_VNNI.

Change-Id: Id12ed38c1648b006c20cf5875a9b2ffe1690ecd6
'}]
commit_message:
CPU: add a trait for AVX512-VNNI support

Add a new standard trait HW_CPU_X86_AVX512VNNI for the support
of CPU AVX512-VNNI instructions.

AVX512-VNNI is the vector network instruction set which is described in
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AVX-512#New_instructions_in_AVX-512_VNNI.

Change-Id: Id12ed38c1648b006c20cf5875a9b2ffe1690ecd6

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-29 12:56:14.000000000', 'message': "[train][goal] Run 'monasca-tempest-influxdb-ipv6-only' job in gate

As part of Train community goal 'Support IPv6-Only Deployments and Testing'[1],
Tempest has defined the base job 'devstack-tempest-ipv6' (adding
in Depends-On patch) which will deploy services on IPv6.

This commit run the new job 'monasca-tempest-influxdb-ipv6-only'
on gate which is derived from 'devstack-tempest-ipv6'.

Verification structure will be:
- 'devstack-IPv6' deploy the service on IPv6
- 'devstack-tempest-ipv6' run will verify the IPv6-only setting and listen address
- 'monasca-tempest-influxdb-ipv6-only' will run the tests.

Story: #2005477
Task: #35906

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671231/
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673274/

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/ipv6-support-and-testing.html

Change-Id: I30dbee4162157f75a808e1c5b6008ca5cba52d28
"}]
commit_message:
[train][goal] Run 'monasca-tempest-influxdb-ipv6-only' job in gate

As part of Train community goal 'Support IPv6-Only Deployments and Testing'[1],
Tempest has defined the base job 'devstack-tempest-ipv6' (adding
in Depends-On patch) which will deploy services on IPv6.

This commit run the new job 'monasca-tempest-influxdb-ipv6-only'
on gate which is derived from 'devstack-tempest-ipv6'.

Verification structure will be:
- 'devstack-IPv6' deploy the service on IPv6
- 'devstack-tempest-ipv6' run will verify the IPv6-only setting and listen address
- 'monasca-tempest-influxdb-ipv6-only' will run the tests.

Story: #2005477
Task: #35906

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671231/
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673274/

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/ipv6-support-and-testing.html

Change-Id: I30dbee4162157f75a808e1c5b6008ca5cba52d28

commit_message:
[train][goal] Define new 'monasca-events-ipv6-only' job in gate

As part of Train community goal 'Support IPv6-Only Deployments and Testing'[1],
Tempest has defined the base job 'devstack-tempest-ipv6' (adding
in Depends-On patch) which will deploy services on IPv6.

This commit adds the new job 'monasca-events-ipv6-only'
run on gate which is derived from 'devstack-tempest-ipv6'.

Verification structure will be:
- 'devstack-IPv6' deploy the service on IPv6
- 'devstack-tempest-ipv6' run will verify the IPv6-only setting and listen address
- 'monasca-events-ipv6-only' will run the tests.

Story: #2005477
Task: #35906

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671231/

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/ipv6-support-and-testing.html

Change-Id: I3f7965c5c1b2001495216fe94465ecf620119220

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-29 10:55:44.000000000', 'message': 'Remove .zuul.yaml from irrelevant-files list

.zuul.yaml defines all the gate jobs and the list of
jobs needs to run on check/gate pipeline etc.

If any job is modified or deleted from run list then
it would not be noticed in same patch whether changes
is fine or not.

This file should not be in irrelevant-files list and
any change in that file has to run all functional or
integrated jobs.

Change-Id: I169b4a9734abb4a11f67cd3481514b7afea5b10d
'}]
commit_message:
Remove .zuul.yaml from irrelevant-files list

.zuul.yaml defines all the gate jobs and the list of
jobs needs to run on check/gate pipeline etc.

If any job is modified or deleted from run list then
it would not be noticed in same patch whether changes
is fine or not.

This file should not be in irrelevant-files list and
any change in that file has to run all functional or
integrated jobs.

Change-Id: I169b4a9734abb4a11f67cd3481514b7afea5b10d

"project_id".

commit_message:
Update api-ref location

The api documentation is now published on docs.openstack.org instead
of developer.openstack.org. Update all links that are changed to the
new location.

Note that redirects will be set up as well but let's point now to the
new location.

For details, see:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/007828.html

Change-Id: Icb170841bacdc5b069c2ff1894615af19d5ab358

The ansible module deployment was broken for private/shared images
because the original request context was not available anymore

commit_message:
Ansible module: fix deployment for private and/or shared images

The ansible module deployment was broken for private/shared images
because the original request context was not available anymore
at the time the image informations were fetched

Change-Id: Id35dcf8ddc209bb8318433d6bf26aba848e074ee
Story: #2006178
Task: #35702

commit_message:
Add a new Event Handler for Octavia

This patch adds a new event handler for Octavia so that in
the event that a network is added to a router, the loadbalancer
on the network are also applied to the router and vice versa.

The process involves:
- Adding a new connection class for Octavia to communicate with
  OVN NB DB, setting up the connection and communicating with
  the IDL.
- Setting up events for Router interface addition and deletion
- Updating Loadbalancer tables and Router/Switch tables based
  upon the generated events.
- Add network UUID to LRP external_ids

Co-Authored-By: Terry Wilson <twilson@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Maciej Jzefczyk <mjozefcz@redhat.com>

Change-Id: If10016325517e4a1fc5f7cfac7f7bd58deb09b54
Closes-Bug: #1794260

commit_message:
Test updating FIP with a different port

The test creates two servers, first one with a floating ip. Then the
floating ip is updated and associated with the port from the second
server and connectivity is checked.

Related-bug: #1835029

Change-Id: I7f48a67af172911d52f62322d2d9fd0222c4c0a1

commit_message:
Skip listener creation with same port of existing one

Due to a bug in Octavia, which does not allows listeners
with same port but different protocols to co-exist, we need
to skip the creation of listeners that have the same port as
an existing one.

Change-Id: Ia96f14e1aff2c4ec9a5fe3fb356107f9c14d462f

commit_message:
Add extra_vars parameter to run_ansible_playbook function

This patch adds a new parameter called 'extra_vars (Defaults to None) to
the 'run_ansible_playbook' function. This parameter will set additional
variables to the 'ansible-playbook' command. It will accept either a
dict or the absolute path of a file (YAML or JSON format).

Change-Id: Ib25ee9593528ad680b14ca09c62addbbd0b773a3
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

Change-Id: Id18ba326da128998d7deb25e305fe2a2150a9f6f
Story: #2005924
Task: #34223

[{'account_id': 30617, 'date': '2019-06-24 10:34:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-06-24 10:34:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:
Switch python3 versions of test jobs to match Train PTI

In Train, we will use python 3.6 and 3.7 for python3 runtime
in our gate jobs [1]. This commit also adds python 3.7.
In Python3.7 async is a reserved keyword so replacing it with is_async.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I05f40c4a9304cad551cefd4f10c3ba9a72d69a6f

[{'created': '2019-07-22 15:22:33.000000000', 'message': 'Add overcloud cell export command

[1] provides the steps on how to setup multiple cells using tripleo.
This requires to extract deployment information from the overcloud
/control plane stack which then is used as input for the cell
deployment.

With this patch we provide a new tripleoclient functionality which

commit_message:
Add overcloud cell export command

[1] provides the steps on how to setup multiple cells using tripleo.
This requires to extract deployment information from the overcloud
/control plane stack which then is used as input for the cell
deployment.

With this patch we provide a new tripleoclient functionality which
helps
to automate the export steps from [1]:
* Export the default cell EndpointMap
* Export the default cell HostsEntry
* Export AllNodesConfig and GlobalConfig information
* Export passwords

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-docs/latest/install/advanced_deployment/deploy_cellv2.html#deploy-an-additional-nova-cell-v2

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/672415

Change-Id: Id7fdbf029a6dd1b45e9801c9cf8814a15a157ee0

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:
Unmount NetApp active share after replica promote

The NetApp cDOT driver is now fixed to unmount the original
active share volume after one of its replica gets promoted.

Change-Id: Iecb734b431f0b7bc9a905b0a672013869ff60fd8
Closes-Bug: #1634278

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

Change-Id: I1094b5f7c166b30e210c540c2e420d8e86894046
Story: #2005924

commit_message:
Add the ability to configure ovn-remote-probe-interval

This parameter sets inactive probe interval of the JSON
session from ovn-controller to the OVN SB database.
By default this it is 5s which not be sufficient in
loaded systems or during high control-plane activity spikes,
leading to unnecessary reconnections to OVSDB server.
Now it is extended by default to 1 min and it
is configurable.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670861/
Change-Id: Ie7cb761ad3b4a180990de2916d6210d15ec0bf50
Closes-Bug: #1836604

commit_message:
Corrected how hiera is installed

Pointing to a static link isn't good - installing EPEL + hiera package
allows to get a smooth test without having to update the package link.

Also uses "prepare.yml" in order to get a cleaner playbook.

Change-Id: I53ac2804d8c2f95ab5831088a70d096a65272c9b

commit_message:
Update docs links

Many links are broken or point to redirect pages, update all of them.

Use better RST for intra-document links so that they do not silently
break if documents move.

Use opendev.org consistently for git.

Change-Id: I8fedff2fff82177fd12da808b8b421270cbe2d95

Introduce a PacemakerTLSPriorities parameter (which will set the
PCMK_tls_priorities config option in /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker and the
PCMK_tls_priorities variable inside the bundle. This, when set, allows
an operator to specify what kind of GNUTLS ciphers are desired for the
pacemaker control port.

Tested on both queens and stein. Via a deploy and a redeploy against
existing cloud. Observed that:

value that was passed in THT

commit_message:
Support TLS priorities for pacemaker

Introduce a PacemakerTLSPriorities parameter (which will set the
PCMK_tls_priorities config option in /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker and the
PCMK_tls_priorities variable inside the bundle. This, when set, allows
an operator to specify what kind of GNUTLS ciphers are desired for the
pacemaker control port.

Tested on both queens and stein. Via a deploy and a redeploy against
existing cloud. Observed that:
A) We got PCMK_tls_priorities inside /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker with the
value that was passed in THT
B) Containers had the following env variable set:
  "PCMK_tls_priorities=normal",

Depends-On: I703b5a429f48063474aace85bc45d948f5c91435
Change-Id: I2a2ea8bfa4da35fa8721b14909b0968123379558

commit_message:
Update api-ref location

The api documentation is now published on docs.openstack.org instead
of developer.openstack.org. Update all links that are changed to the
new location.

Note that redirects will be set up as well but let's point now to the
new location.

For details, see:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/007828.html

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-07 19:17:44.000000000', 'message': 'WIP fup: Replace call to get_capabilities within _has_uefi_support

As discussed in Id97f4baddcf2caff91599773d9b5de5181b7fdf6
_has_uefi_support was previously using a call to Host.get_capabilities
to fetch the host architecture from Libvirt. This can be replaced by a
call to libvirt_utils.get_arch.

Change-Id: I5a91da6d8afd60286bd94e2915b9edb1c995a567
'}]
commit_message:
WIP fup: Replace call to get_capabilities within _has_uefi_support

As discussed in Id97f4baddcf2caff91599773d9b5de5181b7fdf6
_has_uefi_support was previously using a call to Host.get_capabilities
to fetch the host architecture from Libvirt. This can be replaced by a
call to libvirt_utils.get_arch.

Change-Id: I5a91da6d8afd60286bd94e2915b9edb1c995a567

commit_message:
Update api-ref location

The api documentation is now published on docs.openstack.org instead
of developer.openstack.org. Update all links that are changed to the
new location.

Note that redirects will be set up as well but let's point now to the
new location.

For details, see:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/007828.html

Change-Id: I17c97cb7655bdedc3927f4883b45ba4dcfc55516

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-26 14:53:55.000000000', 'message': 'Change ListProjectsStaticTestJSON to not fail with many domains

Changes were made in ListProjectsStaticTestJSON in order to prevent
failure when the os_primary project is not in the default domain.
Instead of checking to see if the projects in question are both in
the default domain, check to see if they are in their respective
correct domains.

Change-Id: I42c3b7a17bfb73079b1d05951636359324bed207
'}, {'created': '2019-07-26 15:31:30.000000000', 'message': 'Skip tests in UsersV3TestJSON with an immutable user source 

Adds a skip_checks condition to UsersV3TestJSON to skip if immutable 
user source is true. resource_setup() in this class attempts to create
users, which will fail if the environment uses an LDAP directory for 
example.

Change-Id: I42c3b7a17bfb73079b1d05951636359324bed207
'}]
commit_message:
Skip tests in UsersV3TestJSON with an immutable user source 

Adds a skip_checks condition to UsersV3TestJSON to skip if immutable 
user source is true. resource_setup() in this class attempts to create
users, which will fail if the environment uses an LDAP directory for 
example.

Change-Id: I42c3b7a17bfb73079b1d05951636359324bed207

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-25 17:23:00.000000000', 'message': 'Adapt TemplatizableDict to python3 hasattr

In python 3, hasattr() expects __getattr__ to raise an AttributeError if
the attribute does not exist. This updates TemplatizableDict accordingly.

Change-Id: I989b5c5d8888bce47fa8c8d7157097d3ea48e0b5
'}]
commit_message:
Adapt TemplatizableDict to python3 hasattr

In python 3, hasattr() expects __getattr__ to raise an AttributeError if
the attribute does not exist. This updates TemplatizableDict accordingly.

Change-Id: I989b5c5d8888bce47fa8c8d7157097d3ea48e0b5

commit_message:
object: Add VirtualPMEM and VirtualPMEMList objs

Introduce the VirtualPMEM object and VirtualPMEMList
object. One VirtualPMEM will correspond to a pmem namespace,
which also means the pmem namespace is assigned to an instance.

Change-Id: I8a86e08ef428f9d5e0ed847d48b055b5988fa07a
Partially-Implements: blueprint virtual-persistent-memory
Co-Authored-By: He Jie Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com>

commit_message:
Properly close web request

Currently this is throwing warnings about unclosed connections. We need
to properly close the response when we try to connect to the container
registries.

Change-Id: Ib93a0edb2e789855aa9e5908130a03ffcd9439c2
Closes-Bug: #1837393
Co-Authored-By: Sorin Sbarnea <ssbarnea@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Getting data from placement when updating datamodel

We have some new fields(vcpus_ratio, vcpus_used, ...)
in the Watcher ComputeNode. During the process of updating
data model by notifications, we need to get data from
placement.

Partially Implements: blueprint improve-compute-data-model

Change-Id: I10587e93bb3e7be6af78bb3a50509d82d8228f78

commit_message:
build universal wheels

Set the flag to ensure universal wheels are built so we can always
install under python 2/3 regardless of how the packages are built.

Change-Id: I38eb50ddcafd804cb33535960a61227fccbeb60a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Show an engine as down if service record is not updated twice

We use the same periodic_interval to update the service record
and compare it with current time when doing 'service list'. So, It's
possible there will be a small window where 'service list' would show
the engine as down. Tools that use service list for monitoring would
wrongly assume the service as down. Let's change service list to
report the service as down if it's not updated in 2*periodic_interval.

Change-Id: I0f6a30e06bb214bb673930b31a2db946600926b0
Task: 35946

messages:
[{'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-05-23 16:04:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-05-24 15:44:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-05-28 14:18:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-05-29 13:11:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 25564, 'date': '2019-05-30 07:13:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27427, 'date': '2019-07-22 18:12:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm a little confused what's going on here Zane, would you mind clarifying?  Is it test_decrypt_dict_invalid_key that's broken and needing amendment, or is this unicode exception the right place to fix this?

Should it be impossible to decrypt with the wrong key?"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-07-26 14:40:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If you use the right key to decrypt then obviously you get out the data you put in when you encrypted (which is presumably well-formed). But if you decrypt with the wrong key then it may successfully decrypt but just return total garbage (random bytes). The garbage may or may not be valid unicode. We have a unit test that tries to decrypt using an incorrect key, and sometimes this occurs - the decryption 'succeeds' but the unicode decoding does not."}, {'account_id': 27427, 'date': '2019-07-26 18:17:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-07-29 02:50:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

Change-Id: I1563962aca8efa30773f03792f7cfd6b7774443d
Task: 33482
'}]
commit_message:
Fix intermittent error in test_decrypt_dict_invalid_key

Sometimes decryption with the wrong key works but produces garbage data.
This is annoying because it occasionally fails the gate at random.

Change-Id: I1563962aca8efa30773f03792f7cfd6b7774443d
Task: 33482

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-27 00:07:39.000000000', 'message': "Never pass 'value_specs' to Neutron

Due to a regression caused by d37cc18b1b7a531edbcf9658600fc467fbe24e2d
that was not caught in the unit tests because of a typo in
6c7e4e4b2f446f7b7678bfc71e5245d10dbf9fcf, we were passing a
'value_specs' field to Neutron when updating an OS::Neutron::Firewall,
OS::Neutron::Net, OS::Neutron::Port, or OS::Neutron::Subnet to remove
existing value_specs. This fixes that to ensure that the 'value_specs'
key is always removed before updating the resource.

Change-Id: I176ab2237c70a5ee78105007e60f841212fef439
Task: 34765
"}, {'created': '2019-07-26 14:43:58.000000000', 'message': "Never pass 'value_specs' to Neutron

that was not caught in the unit tests because of a typo in
6c7e4e4b2f446f7b7678bfc71e5245d10dbf9fcf, we were passing a
'value_specs' field to Neutron when updating an OS::Neutron::Firewall,
OS::Neutron::Net, OS::Neutron::Port, or OS::Neutron::Subnet to remove
existing value_specs. This fixes that to ensure that the 'value_specs'
key is always removed before updating the resource.

Change-Id: I176ab2237c70a5ee78105007e60f841212fef439
Task: 34765
"}]
commit_message:
Never pass 'value_specs' to Neutron

Due to a regression caused by d37cc18b1b7a531edbcf9658600fc467fbe24e2d
that was not caught in the unit tests because of a typo in
6c7e4e4b2f446f7b7678bfc71e5245d10dbf9fcf, we were passing a
'value_specs' field to Neutron when updating an OS::Neutron::Firewall,
OS::Neutron::Net, OS::Neutron::Port, or OS::Neutron::Subnet to remove
existing value_specs. This fixes that to ensure that the 'value_specs'
key is always removed before updating the resource.

Change-Id: I176ab2237c70a5ee78105007e60f841212fef439
Task: 34765

commit_message:
Check resource class before using

check if the resource class(VCPU, memory, disk) in the return
dictionary. If they are, don't need to use dict.get() with a
default value because the parameters are required.

Partially Implements: blueprint improve-compute-data-model

Change-Id: Icb8c672d0e87e6e5f030a2222f928d1bbd069e3c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-05 23:28:46.000000000', 'message': "Allow update of previously-replaced resources

The convergence prototype ignored checks of resources that had previously
been replaced by another resource. However, it turns out that this was
unnecessary in the final version of the prototype:

https://github.com/zaneb/heat-convergence-prototype/commit/e9d2f833a53de1ab09e7d936a4826d36ed7bb68d

Keeping this limitation prevents us from allowing users to roll back to a
previously-existing resource if creating the replacement fails, other than
by using the automated rollback mechanism (which is special-cased).

Since the graph for the traversal is calculated at the start of the update,
there's no need to limit which nodes are allowed to be checked. Only the
selected resource will have an is_update=True node in the traversal graph.
Removing this additional restriction allows us to improve the algorithm
that chooses which resource to update. Since a new traversal ID is stored
before we calculate the traversal graph, we can guarantee that no new
resource checks will start (though some may still be happening) while the
algorithm is choosing, so there's no danger of it picking a resource that
later gets replaced.

Change-Id: I04e7ad90944c2d03ce0e59ba16af9d60d6e01222
Story: #2003579
Task: 26197

unnecessary in the final version of the prototype:

https://github.com/zaneb/heat-convergence-prototype/commit/e9d2f833a53de1ab09e7d936a4826d36ed7bb68d

Keeping this limitation prevents us from allowing users to roll back to a
previously-existing resource if creating the replacement fails, other than
by using the automated rollback mechanism (which is special-cased).

Since the graph for the traversal is calculated at the start of the update,
there's no need to limit which nodes are allowed to be checked. Only the

before we calculate the traversal graph, we can guarantee that no new
resource checks will start (though some may still be happening) while the
algorithm is choosing, so there's no danger of it picking a resource that
later gets replaced.

Since we're no longer treating automatic rollback as a special case, reset
the replaced_by field whenever we update a previously-replaced resource.

Change-Id: I04e7ad90944c2d03ce0e59ba16af9d60d6e01222

Task: 26197

commit_message:
Allow update of previously-replaced resources

The convergence prototype ignored checks of resources that had previously
been replaced by another resource. However, it turns out that this was
unnecessary in the final version of the prototype:

https://github.com/zaneb/heat-convergence-prototype/commit/e9d2f833a53de1ab09e7d936a4826d36ed7bb68d

Keeping this limitation prevents us from allowing users to roll back to a
previously-existing resource if creating the replacement fails, other than
by using the automated rollback mechanism (which is special-cased).

Since the graph for the traversal is calculated at the start of the update,
there's no need to limit which nodes are allowed to be checked. Only the
selected resource will have an is_update=True node in the traversal graph.
Removing this additional restriction allows us to improve the algorithm
that chooses which resource to update. Since a new traversal ID is stored
before we calculate the traversal graph, we can guarantee that no new
resource checks will start (though some may still be happening) while the
algorithm is choosing, so there's no danger of it picking a resource that
later gets replaced.

Since we're no longer treating automatic rollback as a special case, reset
the replaced_by field whenever we update a previously-replaced resource.

Change-Id: I04e7ad90944c2d03ce0e59ba16af9d60d6e01222
Story: #2003579
Task: 26197

commit_message:
Add resource capacity property

Resource(VCPU, memory and disk) capacity need to be calculated
through formula: capacity = (total-reserved)*ratio.

Partially Implements: blueprint improve-compute-data-model

Change-Id: I15ca66dd2c3a21c5acfebf6f04fa6601aff7918f

commit_message:
Fix reporter not report message

There is no message when deploy murano package with
_environment.reporter.report function.
Fix this bug to create Notifier with driver='messaging' parameter.

Change-Id: I34d00d07fba72aedee8dd61bd169b913cbf69fa4
Closes-Bug: #1838009

commit_message:
Update api-ref location

The api documentation is now published on docs.openstack.org instead
of developer.openstack.org. Update all links that are changed to the
new location.

Note that redirects will be set up as well but let's point now to the
new location.

For details, see:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/007828.html

Change-Id: Ibb1b3c39c931e194d7eec0a19aae457d0f73689d

commit_message:
Remove aide puppet manifest

The aide puppet manifest is being removed because the heat template
which invoked it has been converted to ansible. This change removes
the aide manifest and spec files accordingly.

Depends-On: I4479de4c157625be50fdbec33cbf43b30dd7558f

Change-Id: I9d63a38298311909e615e51e1e46dcc35652b351
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

subject: Add library documentation within roles
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-24 12:35:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add library documentation within roles

Roles can have libraries nested within them. This change adds
module documentation to roles whenever the "library" directory
exists. This will ensure all nested libraries are automatically
documeneted.

Change-Id: I7b9d3b1beda62b9941ec9126cb9f3a25a16d74e4
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add library documentation within roles

Roles can have libraries nested within them. This change adds
module documentation to roles whenever the "library" directory
exists. This will ensure all nested libraries are automatically
documeneted.

Change-Id: I7b9d3b1beda62b9941ec9126cb9f3a25a16d74e4
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Re-adding the py35 testing job

ec2api-tempest-plugin is branchless and test all the supported
stable branches including which run on xenial(before stein).

That means ec2api-tempest-plugin code should be able to run on py35
and so does we need py35 testing job which got removed as part of
updating the Train PTI runtime update
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/667087

This commit re-adding the py35 job.
Story: #2005924
Task: #34206

Change-Id: Iab2ff1e4037608b3afca37a2effbf50485d5491c

messages:

If I understand correctly (my knowledge is a little out of date now) the infra-package-needs element is only run to create ephemeral nodepool nodes, but this role looks like it is meant for long-lived nodes running AFS and so ntp will still be needed.'}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2018-06-01 14:15:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-06-01 15:07:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It would be good to update this in any case, but I'm not actually 100% sure any more that this will work for our needs. commit_message:
roles: legacy-install-afs-with-puppet: Bump ntp module to 4.2.0

This is the first version that added support for openSUSE and
SLE, which is needed for the effort of enabling opensuse
in the nodepool building

Diff is rather big:
https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppetlabs-ntp/compare/3.2.x...4.2.0

Link: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/447058/
Change-Id: I881266b5a71561d36d15924b7e99452c50ecad31

commit_message:
Reparent ozj integration jobs to base-test for testing

We want to test if ara is only generated on failures. base-test has been
updated to do this so reparent some tests to base-test.

Change-Id: Ic0822387bd4f70894957725f06c758da40006545

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-project-config-layout http://logs.openstack.org/25/434625/3/check/gate-project-config-layout/6106908/ : SUCCESS in 10m 05s
- gate-project-config-linters-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/25/434625/3/check/gate-project-config-linters-ubuntu-xenial/6722a0e/ : SUCCESS in 1m 44s
- gate-project-config-jenkins-project http://logs.openstack.org/25/434625/3/check/gate-project-config-jenkins-project/8e1a2fe/ : SUCCESS in 1m 17s'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2017-02-16 21:22:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

So here's the thing the intent here to leverage subunit2sql (or at least the tooling around it) makes total sense. But the method you're trying to go about doing this won't actually work in practice. The biggest issue with this is that the subunit gearman worker is configured to just ignore all attachments from the subunit stream when it writes to the db. This is done for very practical reason, mostly it takes upa huge amount of space. The second problem is you'll be polluting the test data in subunit2sql with the fake_test your using for the attachment. The subunit protocol doesn't actually say that attachments need a test_id, so you can just add the data to the subunit stream without a test_id. I included some sample code (I mostly stole from openstack/os-performance-tools on how to do this)

How I think we should go about this is to leverage the infrastructure SpamapS set up to do the same exact thing with counters data from openstack/os-performance-tools (although he never got around to setting it up) The basic approach there was to leverage a target extension (https://docs.openstack.org/developer/subunit2sql/target-extensions.html ) to pull the attachment from the subunit when subunit2sql start processing it and then send that somewhere we're aggregating the data."}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-02-17 04:29:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

ok, that seems to make sense.

so i would add this as an extension in os-performance-tools

i have to understand the layout of subunit2sql more ... but would you think this would be an extra field (coverage) for one of the existing models?  or would it have to be in a separate table?'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-02-23 04:20:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-02-23 04:30:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-project-config-layout http://logs.openstack.org/25/434625/4/check/gate-project-config-layout/b5f6fc9/ : SUCCESS in 8m 38s
- gate-project-config-linters-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/25/434625/4/check/gate-project-config-linters-ubuntu-xenial/42c0b86/ : SUCCESS in 59s
- gate-project-config-jenkins-project http://logs.openstack.org/25/434625/4/check/gate-project-config-jenkins-project/83a6760/ : SUCCESS in 44s'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-02-23 04:43:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

As mentioned, this is fully explained in the spec at Ia4a4bfe075e877246500f4b3e0fc47eb408994f8'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2017-10-29 14:07:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

We have switched to Zuul v3 now, this change does not apply anymore.

Learn on how to update your change with Zuul v3 at
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/zuulv3.html .

Simplified:
* Job definitions can be in-repo; common job definitions are in
  openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs repository
* Job scheduling can be done in-repo for project specific changes,
  common jobs are configured via
  openstack-infra/project-config/zuul.d/projects.yaml

Read the above mentioned document for finer details.

Please decide whether this change is still needed and then adopt if
for Zuul v3 or abandon it.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-07-28 17:37:59.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

needs to be done in other repos nowadays'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-02-16 03:53:16.000000000', 'message': 'Coverage: add and store subunit stream for coverage stats

Without some sort of tracking, it's not really possible to know if
coverage is trending up or down.  As a result, it is clear from the
logs that the detailed coverage reports get little direct inspection.
We already have the openstack-health dashboard which queries test data
injected via subunit2sql.  By making coverage data available there, we
can extend this tool to track overall coverage rates.

The coverage tool does not have any direct subunit output facility.
We create a "fake" test that uses the usual subunit runner and
attaches a coverage XML report as an artifact.  We run this test after
the coverage run and create a testrepository.subunit output file.  We
add this to the log-copy.

This will then be processed by the logstash workers (see [1] -- the
post queue already collects this if there).  From there, we should be
able to do a query on post-queue coverage jobs, extract the coverage
rate for each and produce a graph.

This was inspired by comments on the cleanup in
I4e64bb803929f1dbaef26bf513d3a0afa91484d8.  The plan is to standardise
that coverage jobs run the check queue (so you get visibility if they
are broken or not) and in the post queue for overall tracking.

To get thing going, this adds creation of the coverage.xml if it does
not exist but seems like it could.  Long term I think PBR should
generate this, seeIdd54ecc627896cc5eab4903658f10a344bdb1778.

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/system-config/tree/modules/openstack_project/files/logstash/jenkins-log-client.yaml#n14

Change-Id: I4cecd7c719b0ec3c742ada2b13f0dba4c262795b

We would like to add tracking for coverage rates over time.  It is
clear from the logs that the detailed coverage reports get little
direct inspection, probably due to this lack of an overview.  We
already have the openstack-health dashboard which queries test data
injected via subunit2sql.  By making coverage data available there, we
can extend this tool to track overall coverage rates.

The coverage tool does not have any direct subunit output facility.
We create a "fake" test that tags itself with the overall coverage
numbers and attaches the coverage report as an artifact, putting its
output into a subunit stream "testrepository.subunit".

This will then be processed into the openstack-health database via the
normal mechanisms.

For details, see the spec at Ia4a4bfe075e877246500f4b3e0fc47eb408994f8

This was inspired by comments on the cleanup in
I4e64bb803929f1dbaef26bf513d3a0afa91484d8.  The plan is to standardise
that coverage jobs run the check queue (so you get visibility if they
are broken or not) and in the post queue for overall tracking.

To get thing going, this adds creation of the coverage.xml if it does
not exist but seems like it could.  Long term I think PBR should
generate this, see Idd54ecc627896cc5eab4903658f10a344bdb1778.

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/system-config/tree/modules/openstack_project/files/logstash/jenkins-log-client.yaml#n14

Change-Id: I4cecd7c719b0ec3c742ada2b13f0dba4c262795b
'}]
commit_message:
Coverage: add and store subunit stream for coverage stats

We would like to add tracking for coverage rates over time.  It is
clear from the logs that the detailed coverage reports get little
direct inspection, probably due to this lack of an overview.  We
already have the openstack-health dashboard which queries test data
injected via subunit2sql.  By making coverage data available there, we
can extend this tool to track overall coverage rates.

The coverage tool does not have any direct subunit output facility.
We create a "fake" test that tags itself with the overall coverage
numbers and attaches the coverage report as an artifact, putting its
output into a subunit stream "testrepository.subunit".

This will then be processed into the openstack-health database via the
normal mechanisms.

For details, see the spec at Ia4a4bfe075e877246500f4b3e0fc47eb408994f8

This was inspired by comments on the cleanup in
I4e64bb803929f1dbaef26bf513d3a0afa91484d8.  The plan is to standardise
that coverage jobs run the check queue (so you get visibility if they
are broken or not) and in the post queue for overall tracking.

To get thing going, this adds creation of the coverage.xml if it does
not exist but seems like it could.  Long term I think PBR should
generate this, see Idd54ecc627896cc5eab4903658f10a344bdb1778.

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/system-config/tree/modules/openstack_project/files/logstash/jenkins-log-client.yaml#n14

Change-Id: I4cecd7c719b0ec3c742ada2b13f0dba4c262795b

commit_message:
Use canonical hostname when setting up network ports

The hostname used to set the binding host for Octavia health manager
needs to match the hostname expected by the neutron L2 agent in order
for port binding to succeed. The canonical hostname from the
tripleo ansible inventory might be a better match than the hostname used
in group vars.

Related-Bug: #1837043
Depends-On: I5d23b02ca46a40b39dc25a8367541b0a6e517982
Change-Id: Ie0cf35d95c7632e904bc7be9fbc856b7ff0d21ca

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I717874850cc237a1a049265560b4c7b09ffbe496

subject: Ensure Cinder has a default volume type
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-24 15:16:54.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure Cinder has a default volume type

This patch adds a CinderDefaultVolumeType parameter, and does two
things:

1. Configures the default_volume_type in /etc/cinder/cinder.conf
2. Ensures the volume type exists

The cinder::api puppet module supports configuring the default_volume_type,
and this patch simply sets the corresponding hiera value.

The cinder::type puppet resource is used to ensure the default volume
type exists. This is done using docker_puppet_tasks so that it executes
after the Cinder services are running. This is necessary because the
cinder::type puppet provider executes osc commands.

Closes-Bug: #1782217
Depends-On: Ia23996abefdd1410fb86f04ed84a314f4364339c
Change-Id: I99496aa82bb66eccd86f0e482f1fbdc656c07c5d
(cherry picked from commit 1433d5819f01631314dd3ea93f02583d7d5ae3eb)
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure Cinder has a default volume type

This patch adds a CinderDefaultVolumeType parameter, and does two
things:

1. Configures the default_volume_type in /etc/cinder/cinder.conf
2. Ensures the volume type exists

The cinder::api puppet module supports configuring the default_volume_type,
and this patch simply sets the corresponding hiera value.

The cinder::type puppet resource is used to ensure the default volume
type exists. This is done using docker_puppet_tasks so that it executes
after the Cinder services are running. This is necessary because the
cinder::type puppet provider executes osc commands.

Closes-Bug: #1782217
Depends-On: Ia23996abefdd1410fb86f04ed84a314f4364339c
Change-Id: I99496aa82bb66eccd86f0e482f1fbdc656c07c5d
(cherry picked from commit 1433d5819f01631314dd3ea93f02583d7d5ae3eb)

commit_message:
Cap the maximum number of rpc workers

Currently, there is only one process for all
rabbitmq processing. This is not enough and
causes systems to get clogged up.

Change-Id: Ie4823ed85582d3056c7837e3a8a4e7a53fac653c
(cherry picked from commit 164cc66f7df1d35ae5d69bb996e9d5fe02ca8128)

subject: Enhance parsing of domain capabilities and track canonical machine types
messages: [{'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-07-27 21:27:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-07-27 21:31:01.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nDoh, this was accidentally created by the result of a fixup commit being squashed into the original without removing the new Change-Id.  Sorry for the noise.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-27 21:27:21.000000000', 'message': "Enhance parsing of domain capabilities and track canonical machine types

Currently we're only calling libvirt's getDomainCapabilities API once
per architecture, with the assumption that covering a single machine
type (the default) for that architecture is enough.  However, the
default for x86_64 is 'pc', but we need domain capabilities for 'q35'
in order to boot SEV guests.  So for x86_64, we need domain
capabilities for at least two machine types: 'pc' and 'q35'.

We can obtain a sensibly small list of machine types with which to
call getDomainCapabilities by looking for the 'canonical' attribute in
machine types returned from getCapabilities (N.B. not
getDomainCapabilities). For example, getCapabilities returns these:

    <machine canonical='pc-i440fx-2.11' maxCpus='255'>pc</machine>
    <machine canonical='pc-q35-2.11' maxCpus='288'>q35</machine>

So change Host.get_domain_capabilities() to call the API not just with
the default machine type, but also once per canonical machine type.

In order to obtain the canonical machine types, enhance config.py so
that it can extract them from the capabilities XML, modernize the
fixtures for x86 capabilities so that they include the q35 family of
machine types, and add corresponding tests.  A new class
LibvirtConfigCapsGuestDomain is introduced to model the elements of
the capabilities XML such as <domain type='kvm'>, and their associated
machine types.  This supersedes the previous domtype attribute of
LibvirtConfigCapsGuest objects.  Canonical machine types are tracked
separately from the others in order to allow
Host.get_domain_capabilities to invoke libvirt's getDomainCapabilities
only on those types.

As before, we register both the shortened canonical (alias) machine
type (e.g. 'q35') plus its full expanded counterpart (e.g. 'pc-q35-2.11')
if that is different.

As Host.get_domain_capabilities() is already long and complex, and
needs more functionality adding to support these changes, split out
much of the code into smaller methods:

    - _get_machine_types()
    - _add_to_domain_capabilities()

The new tests require extending assertXmlEqual to pass through to
matcher.XMLMatches any options which the latter supports.  In
particular this allows the allow_mixed_nodes option to be enabled to
compare XML fragments with elements in different orders, since the
children of <arch> generated by LibvirtConfigCapsGuest.format_dom have
the non-canonical machine types first, followed by the canonical ones.

The tests also require removing the 'bamboo' canonical machine type
for the ppc architecture, since the getDomainCapabilities fixture for
this architecture is static and only returns results with a fixed
g3beige machine type which would cause a mismatch when called with the
'bamboo' machine type.  The x86 fixtures are sufficient to test these
code paths, so this is a simpler alternative to adding complexity to
the ppc fixtures.

In the process of testing, a bug was discovered in
test_driver.LibvirtConnTestCase.test_cpu_info and
test_driver.LibvirtConnTestCase.test_get_instance_capabilities where
it was incorrectly adding LibvirtConfigGuest fixture objects to the
guests attribute of LibvirtConfigCaps.  This was fixed to instead add
LibvirtConfigCapsGuest fixtures, the construction of which is adjusted
to the new class model.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: I9da9ce682dc8c8b72fb31dd4e732b556b2ed7f90

squash! Enhance parsing of domain capabilities and track canonical machine types

Change-Id: I361490a439422ef5e2cec96f022f0a2f4e8cb2db
"}]
commit_message:
Enhance parsing of domain capabilities and track canonical machine types

Currently we're only calling libvirt's getDomainCapabilities API once
per architecture, with the assumption that covering a single machine
type (the default) for that architecture is enough.  However, the
default for x86_64 is 'pc', but we need domain capabilities for 'q35'
in order to boot SEV guests.  So for x86_64, we need domain
capabilities for at least two machine types: 'pc' and 'q35'.

We can obtain a sensibly small list of machine types with which to
call getDomainCapabilities by looking for the 'canonical' attribute in
machine types returned from getCapabilities (N.B. not
getDomainCapabilities). For example, getCapabilities returns these:

    <machine canonical='pc-i440fx-2.11' maxCpus='255'>pc</machine>
    <machine canonical='pc-q35-2.11' maxCpus='288'>q35</machine>

So change Host.get_domain_capabilities() to call the API not just with
the default machine type, but also once per canonical machine type.

In order to obtain the canonical machine types, enhance config.py so
that it can extract them from the capabilities XML, modernize the
fixtures for x86 capabilities so that they include the q35 family of
machine types, and add corresponding tests.  A new class
LibvirtConfigCapsGuestDomain is introduced to model the elements of
the capabilities XML such as <domain type='kvm'>, and their associated
machine types.  This supersedes the previous domtype attribute of
LibvirtConfigCapsGuest objects.  Canonical machine types are tracked
separately from the others in order to allow
Host.get_domain_capabilities to invoke libvirt's getDomainCapabilities
only on those types.

As before, we register both the shortened canonical (alias) machine
type (e.g. 'q35') plus its full expanded counterpart (e.g. 'pc-q35-2.11')
if that is different.

As Host.get_domain_capabilities() is already long and complex, and
needs more functionality adding to support these changes, split out
much of the code into smaller methods:

    - _get_machine_types()
    - _add_to_domain_capabilities()

The new tests require extending assertXmlEqual to pass through to
matcher.XMLMatches any options which the latter supports.  In
particular this allows the allow_mixed_nodes option to be enabled to
compare XML fragments with elements in different orders, since the
children of <arch> generated by LibvirtConfigCapsGuest.format_dom have
the non-canonical machine types first, followed by the canonical ones.

The tests also require removing the 'bamboo' canonical machine type
for the ppc architecture, since the getDomainCapabilities fixture for
this architecture is static and only returns results with a fixed
g3beige machine type which would cause a mismatch when called with the
'bamboo' machine type.  The x86 fixtures are sufficient to test these
code paths, so this is a simpler alternative to adding complexity to
the ppc fixtures.

In the process of testing, a bug was discovered in
test_driver.LibvirtConnTestCase.test_cpu_info and
test_driver.LibvirtConnTestCase.test_get_instance_capabilities where
it was incorrectly adding LibvirtConfigGuest fixture objects to the
guests attribute of LibvirtConfigCaps.  This was fixed to instead add
LibvirtConfigCapsGuest fixtures, the construction of which is adjusted
to the new class model.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: I9da9ce682dc8c8b72fb31dd4e732b556b2ed7f90

squash! Enhance parsing of domain capabilities and track canonical machine types

Change-Id: I361490a439422ef5e2cec96f022f0a2f4e8cb2db

Actually we need to think about this a little more.

There are cases where the user really doesn't want to do any prepare operations because they've already prepared the images and are supplying the image parameters in the environment.

Currently, supplying no ContainerImagePrepare parameter means "do not prepare", but this changes that meaning to be "prepare with defaults".

We can make this change, but we need to determine what the user does to specify "do not prepare". Maybe a new boolean parameter? Maybe a check for ContainerImagePrepare:[]?'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-02-28 15:03:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-02-28 15:52:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Use the default ContainerImagePrepare if not provided

Previously before we enabled ovn by default, you didn't actually have to
specify a ContainerImagePrepare statement for a basic deploy to work.
Now that we have enabled ovn by default, we need to properly evaluate
the environment to determine which neutron related containers will be
needed.

Change-Id: I2147dcbe1c0247c49f13dbe5538694124886041b

commit_message:
Add the ability to parse list only files

This change will allow config_template to parse list only files
and extend or replace the content of the list based on the
selected module options.

Change-Id: I2a24033b0323bcc25bd1b50ffb4034441ab2f468
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add ssh configuration for minion

Currently once the install is complete, a user is locked out which isn't
ideal. Let's manage the ssh like we do for the undercloud as well.

Closes-Bug: #1837942

commit_message:
Re-Add facter cache for container configurations

Rather than running all the facts for every invocation of
container-puppet.py, let's cache the facts for the entire container
config step.  This is similar to what used to happen when we ran puppet
in a single instance for a given step. This improves the time it takes
puppet tp execute within the containers. When systems have large number
of interfaces, the fact generation for puppet can come to a crawl given
that puppet is not supposed to be invoked multiple times in parallel. By
pre-caching the facts, we eliminate the need for puppet to do the
network (and other fact) related lookups when running container
configuration generation.

This patch includes logic to exclude the puppet caching dirs that we
mount as read only in the config containers.

Conflicts:
	common/container-puppet.py

Change-Id: I94002572ec7ac1767fbfbfdf4c6fa6fbf0cd58d5
Closes-Bug: #1837082
Closes-Bug: #1835959
(cherry picked from commit 08e34dbcaebb0608df61d6540d4919cab71632f5)

commit_message:
Re-Add facter cache for container configurations

Rather than running all the facts for every invocation of
container-puppet.py, let's cache the facts for the entire container
config step.  This is similar to what used to happen when we ran puppet
in a single instance for a given step. This improves the time it takes
puppet tp execute within the containers. When systems have large number
of interfaces, the fact generation for puppet can come to a crawl given
that puppet is not supposed to be invoked multiple times in parallel. By
pre-caching the facts, we eliminate the need for puppet to do the

mount as read only in the config containers.

commit_message:
Update api-ref location

The api documentation is now published on docs.openstack.org instead
of developer.openstack.org. Update all links that are changed to the
new location.

Note that redirects will be set up as well but let's point now to the
new location.

For details, see:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/007828.html

More investigation required.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-07-27 16:39:36.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-26 14:36:49.000000000', 'message': 'Remove deprecated and incorrect config from magnum.conf

auth_uri is deprecated and is no longer used by magnum as of the S
release. auth_uri is replaced by www_authenticate_uri in the
keystone_authtoken config section, which is already present.

www_authenticate_uri should not be in the keystone_auth section of the
config file and is removed.

Change-Id: I18403f012fa036fabdbd8798aaf922a67eb9303f
'}]
commit_message:
Remove deprecated and incorrect config from magnum.conf

auth_uri is deprecated and is no longer used by magnum as of the S
release. auth_uri is replaced by www_authenticate_uri in the
keystone_authtoken config section, which is already present.

www_authenticate_uri should not be in the keystone_auth section of the
config file and is removed.

Change-Id: I18403f012fa036fabdbd8798aaf922a67eb9303f

subject: Upgrade ceph to mimic release
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 538, 'name': 'Major Hayden', 'email': 'major@mhtx.net', 'username': 'rackerhacker'}, {'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 2799, 'name': 'Andy McCrae', 'email': 'andy.mccrae@googlemail.com', 'username': 'andrew-mccrae'}, {'_account_id': 6816, 'name': 'Jesse Pretorius', 'email': 'jesse@odyssey4.me', 'username': 'jesse-pretorius'}, {'_account_id': 7353, 'name': 'Kevin Carter', 'email': 'kevin@cloudnull.com', 'username': 'cloudnull'}, {'_account_id': 7414, 'name': 'David Wilde', 'email': 'dwilde@redhat.com', 'username': 'd34dh0r53'}, {'_account_id': 12402, 'name': 'Robb Romans', 'email': 'robb.romans@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rromans'}, {'_account_id': 13095, 'name': 'Marc Garipy', 'email': 'gariepy.marc@gmail.com', 'username': 'mgariepy'}, {'_account_id': 14805, 'name': 'Jimmy McCrory', 'email': 'jimmy.mccrory@gmail.com', 'username': 'jimmy-mccrory'}, {'_account_id': 15993, 'name': 'Amy Marrich', 'display_name': 'Amy Marrich (spotz)', 'email': 'amy@demarco.com', 'username': 'amarrich'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 17799, 'name': 'Logan V', 'email': 'logan2211@gmail.com', 'username': 'Logan2211'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23163, 'name': 'Markos Chandras (hwoarang)', 'email': 'markos@chandras.me', 'username': 'mchandras'}, {'_account_id': 25023, 'name': 'Jonathan Rosser', 'email': 'jonathan.rosser@rd.bbc.co.uk', 'username': 'jrosser'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2018-10-28 10:54:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2018-10-31 10:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I am skeptical about doing such an update on a stable branch'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2018-10-31 11:53:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I am skeptical about doing such an update on a stable branch

dowloads.ceph.com provides:

Luminous for trusty/xenial
Mimic for xenial/bionic

UCA provides:

Queens/luminous packages in the xenial repo but apparently built for bionic :(
Rocky/mimic on bionic

I don't really know what to suggest other than point out that currently ceph/bionic on Rocky is broken as shown in the gate checks here https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614320/"}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2018-10-31 13:01:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I understand but ubuntu is not the only target here and this is a stable branch so not sure if bumping ceph at this point is a safe thing to do. Let me add the rest of the cores in this review and see what they think'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2018-11-26 21:59:54.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-02-13 11:39:15.000000000', 'content': 'Restored

Restoring this to investigate ceph/bionic/rocky package install failures'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-02-13 11:39:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-02-13 12:55:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I would suggest that first prize is to make the pinning work properly, because ideally we don't want to change a major version of ceph mid-release. We may have to set the priority to 1001 to force it to use the ceph repositories and we may also possibly have to change the order of installs to ensure the right version is installed first.

Alternatively, we could do a minor version increment to 18.2.0 and a release note describing that the Ceph version has been updated to mimic with an explanation for why that was done.

I wonder whether RDO and SUSE have their own preferred packaged versions, much like UCA, and whether we shouldn't try to use those instead as a default by setting the source for ceph, by default, to be 'distro' so that no new repositories are added and it'll just use whatever's in OBS/RDO/UCA. That may require some other settings changes to make sure that ceph-ansible behaves properly - I don't know whether it has any release-specific settings."}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-02-13 13:48:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I would suggest that first prize is to make the pinning work
 > properly, because ideally we don't want to change a major version
 > of ceph mid-release. We may have to set the priority to 1001 to
 > force it to use the ceph repositories and we may also possibly have
 > to change the order of installs to ensure the right version is
 > installed first.
 > 

Just to add amusement:

Rocky is *already* installing mimic from UCA as seen here: http://logs.openstack.org/80/613780/2/check/openstack-ansible-deploy-aio_ceph-ubuntu-bionic/95034da/logs/openstack/aio1_cinder_volumes_container-d0fccc21/apt/history.log.txt.gz

download.ceph.com does not provide packages for luminous on bionic:
http://download.ceph.com/debian-luminous/pool/main/c/ceph/

 > Alternatively, we could do a minor version increment to 18.2.0 and
 > a release note describing that the Ceph version has been updated to
 > mimic with an explanation for why that was done.

Well w're already deploying mimic - just not realising it :)
 
 > I wonder whether RDO and SUSE have their own preferred packaged
 > versions, much like UCA, and whether we shouldn't try to use those
 > instead as a default by setting the source for ceph, by default, to
 > be 'distro' so that no new repositories are added and it'll just
 > use whatever's in OBS/RDO/UCA.

It would certainly simplify things but we need to leave a specific hook for a non UCA ceph source, as the ceph_client role could well need to integrate with an external ceph cluster deployed from any source."}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-02-13 13:56:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Well then, it sounds like we need to do an 18.2.0 with a reno... and get the bionic/ceph gate passing.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-02-13 14:42:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Well then, it sounds like we need to do an 18.2.0 with a reno...
 > and get the bionic/ceph gate passing.

Oh and also xenial/rocky *will* install luminous, because UCA doesnt provide packages for xenial/rocky, so we use UCA xenial/queens which has luminous. *Sigh*'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-02-20 09:46:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-02-21 09:03:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

So I guess it makes sense then to do some sort of conditional so that we have xenial/rocky/luminous and bionic/rocky/mimic and the ceph-ansible plays do the right things? We then need to just make it clear in the release notes (and perhaps some docs) that this is the case.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-07-27 16:36:18.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Remove name2int

Aiming to remove name2int module from openstack-ansible-plugins.
Removed use of module, using string_2_int filter instead.

Change-Id: I37574f943422f31f14ba12fb25a0d00638d97637
Related-Bug: #1826243

[{'created': '2019-07-22 11:34:21.000000000', 'message': "Don't crash ovs agent during reconfigure of phys bridges

In case when physical bridge was recreated on host, ovs agent
is trying to reconfigure it.
If there will be e.g. timeout while getting bridge's datapath_id,
RuntimeError will be raised and that caused crash of whole agent.

This patch changes that to not crash agent in such case but try to

Change-Id: Ic9b17a420068c0c76748e2c24d97be1ed7c460c7

commit_message:
Don't crash ovs agent during reconfigure of phys bridges

In case when physical bridge was recreated on host, ovs agent
is trying to reconfigure it.
If there will be e.g. timeout while getting bridge's datapath_id,
RuntimeError will be raised and that caused crash of whole agent.

This patch changes that to not crash agent in such case but try to
reconfigure everything in next rpc_loop iteration once again.

Change-Id: Ic9b17a420068c0c76748e2c24d97be1ed7c460c7
Closes-Bug: #1837380

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I92f9026d64babc60cb93edd4aba17508f7e5e653

commit_message:
[api-ref] Correct share metadata API ref

- Clarify the difference between PUT and POST
  on the /shares/<ID>/metadata URL
- Add ref for API to retrieve a single metadata
  item
- Add more notes regarding API behavior

commit_message:
Adds "unset" action to the member command

This patch adds "openstack loadbalancer member unset" action to the
octavia client. This allows the user to unset the name, backup,
etc. setings.

This is a patch in a chain adding "unset" to all of the octavia
commands. A follow on patch will include the release note.

Change-Id: I418f8040364942425f396dfc85ae10984d93fae4

Adds "unset" action to the pool command

This patch adds "openstack loadbalancer pool unset" action to the
octavia client. This allows the user to unset the name, description,
etc. setings.

This is a patch in a chain adding "unset" to all of the octavia
commands. A follow on patch will include the release note.

Swift gate does not run integrated-gate jobs which are
tempest-full and grenade-py3 job. Tempest-full job run
all services tests. But all services tests are not needed
to run on swift gate because it does not depends on all services.

Tempest has prepared the new jobs for swift gate which will run
only Swift, Cinder and Glance related tests.

the tempest-integrated-object-storage and grenade-py3 jobs

commit_message:
Add integrated gate tempest and grenade job

Swift gate does not run integrated-gate jobs which are
tempest-full and grenade-py3 job. Tempest-full job run
all services tests. But all services tests are not needed
to run on swift gate because it does not depends on all services.

Tempest has prepared the new jobs for swift gate which will run
only Swift, Cinder and Glance related tests.

New template 'integrated-gate-object-storage'(Depends-On) includes
the tempest-integrated-object-storage and grenade-py3 jobs

This commit adds the new integrated-gate template in swift gate.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670353/
Change-Id: Ia0543dca729c3a2aa67ce9f560c1ce5976c00abf

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-27 04:48:51.000000000', 'message': "symlink: Include the links that led to symloop_max

We already have this available in the stack; may as well let the client
see. Besides, suppose you have

  A -> B -> C -> D

You realize you exceeded the limit, and try to make

  A -> B' -> D

However, you might *still* get 409s when you GET A (because of eventual
consistency), and we ought to help you understand *why*.

Change-Id: Ibe5fa4c250dc47edff3221bc6e797301a051ecb5
"}]
commit_message:
symlink: Include the links that led to symloop_max

We already have this available in the stack; may as well let the client
see. Besides, suppose you have

  A -> B -> C -> D

You realize you exceeded the limit, and try to make

  A -> B' -> D

However, you might *still* get 409s when you GET A (because of eventual
consistency), and we ought to help you understand *why*.

Change-Id: Ibe5fa4c250dc47edff3221bc6e797301a051ecb5

commit_message:
Remove unused FP device creation and deletion methods.

These methods aren't used anywhere, so just remove them.

Change-Id: Ic04a6a76701e738d911a2e9018afa252b57092be

(3 comments)

You need also to add this new extension to the list of enabled extensions which will be set in tempest config file. You should do it in .zuul.yaml file in this repo.'}, {'account_id': 30156, 'date': '2019-07-22 19:48:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Slawek, question: if we add the extension to .zuul.yaml but then have tests that do not have the extension in required_extensions, are the tests running with or without the extension enabled?'}, {'account_id': 24797, 'date': '2019-07-22 23:15:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 24797, 'date': '2019-07-22 23:15:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-07-23 08:24:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

> Slawek, question: if we add the extension to .zuul.yaml but then
 > have tests that do not have the extension in required_extensions,
 > are the tests running with or without the extension enabled?

tempest is checking if extensions listed in required_extensions list are available in tempest config file. If some of required_extension is missing from this list, test is skipped.

I gave -1 only because of missing extension in .zuul.yaml file. Because of that all new tests are now skipped and can't be run at all."}, {'account_id': 24797, 'date': '2019-07-23 17:19:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 24797, 'date': '2019-07-23 17:21:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Add tempest tests for DVR router state management

Add positive and negative tempest tests that assert correct operation of
a DVR router when the extension 'router-admin-state-down-before-update'
is enabled.
Added extension to neutron-tempest-plugin job.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/625134/
Change-Id: Iaf24afa3d0fc28f2bec7be1b705a8d8b5ff886f8
Signed-off-by: Matt Welch <matt.welch@intel.com>

commit_message:
Make Ubuntu bionic the default for amphora images

This patch updates the diskimage-create script to select Ubuntu
bionic as the default version of Ubuntu for the amphora image.

Change-Id: Ie8bbcbe073644137b8eb04c42d9457f507513007

subject: set disk field to disk capacity
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-26 09:28:00.000000000', 'message': 'set disk field to disk capacity

The node.free_disk_gb does not take allocation ratios used
for overcommit into account so this value may be negative.
We do not need this field and plan to set disk to total disk
capacity and then remove disk_capacity.

Partially Implements: blueprint improve-compute-data-model

Change-Id: I72c4490f5a8d0fbd1039f70ff20f07b743b6bb2d
'}]
commit_message:
set disk field to disk capacity

The node.free_disk_gb does not take allocation ratios used
for overcommit into account so this value may be negative.
We do not need this field and plan to set disk to total disk
capacity and then remove disk_capacity.

Partially Implements: blueprint improve-compute-data-model

Change-Id: I72c4490f5a8d0fbd1039f70ff20f07b743b6bb2d

commit_message:
Bump the openstackdocstheme extension to 1.20

Some options are now automatically configured by the version 1.20:
- project
- html_last_updated_fmt
- latex_engine
- latex_elements
- version
- release.

Change-Id: I2e12b3da4686bf9f18d55fbb629d8a4525f3bc8d
